ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned a bunch of bones
I learned the names and features of the bones of the body. We learned how to identify them from pictures.
I learned about the osteology of humans.
Learned bones and features of bones in body. Also learned some myology.
Human anatomy--bones and muscles!
There is a lot of information not just on the names of bones, but also how they are formed, how they develop, and how they work together with the rest of the body.
A better understanding of whole-body muscle and bone strucutre.
Knowledge of all of the body's bones and some muscles and ligaments
I learned how to identify and describe the function of bones.
A decent (and pretty broad) overview of the human skeleton, which (you guessed it) has a LOT of bones.

I learned a great deal about the human skeletonwe not only covered bones themselves (and many of them), but also their features, related soft tissue, and how to do estimations (e.g. sex, age) from bones.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Doesn't really work virtually - would be much better if we could see the real bones
Eric was very kind. But the class was still very hard to engage with without the actual bones.
Grading was fair and expectations for the class were clear. However, there is no extra credit and so if you have to miss a lab or a quiz, your grade can take a hit.
This course was interesting, but also required a large deal of memorization. I imagine the class would be a lot better in person but overall still a good science credit

Strengths- class is very straightforward
Weaknesses- I did dedicate a LOT of time to memorization and studying for quizzes.
Only wish it could have been in person!

This was a difficult course to do virtually because we were not able to do any labs in person. It would be nice to have an in-person element. However, the lectures provided a lot of interesting information that supported the key material we had to know for the quizzes.
Course was well organized for learning and review sessions were helpful.

Strengths: simplicity, Sargis and the TA's are kind and helpful
Weaknesses: wish there could be a little more interaction virtually. There probably is more in person.
It was a really well-taught course, despite being virtual.

Strengths: Really great online resources, and very informational slides. It's really easy to go into the slides and online study guides and know exactly what you need to know for the quizzes. 
Weaknesses: Over Zoom, it was sometimes difficult to focus during the lectures because most of the info you need to know for quizzes is stuff you just have to memorize.

The strengths of this course were clear expectations (all the labs and quizzes were quite transparent, and we were always well prepared for them), a knowledgeable professor and TA, and really interesting material. I don't know that any weaknesses come to mind, though of course it would have been ideal to have it in person.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I understand that it was online, but it felt very unrealistic. We were asked to side bones from isolated images of the bone. In reality, we would be presented with the whole bone and have several ways to identify its side, for examples. But, the labs were very helpful.

Labs are certainly harder to do virtually. I feel like it would have been useful for the prof or the TA to go through the labeling of a 3D bone model as a class. This would have made studying and siding easier, instead of just having the prof explain a 2D picture of a bone.
The lectures were well taught, but there is not much that could be done to allow for in person labs during covid.
Lectures were engaging and websites provided were very helpful.
I think this was a hard class to do virtually. I definitely wish it could have been in person, but the Professor adjusted the expectations to the virtual format in a very fair way.
Course adapted well to online format and grading was fair.
N/A
The online resources we used to look over skeletons were REALLY helpful (eSkeletons and SketchFab), especially because we didn't have access to actual physical bones.

Although it would have been great to have this lab in person and actually be able to handle samples, etc., the virtual resources for visualizing bones and the skeleton were quite good, and Professor Sargis was generous in adapting what we were required to know for assessments based on what was feasible virtually.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great class and professor. You learn a lot and know what's expected of you for exams which makes doing well easy.

Yes. If you are not a science person this is a good class to get a science credit from. Lots of memorization and not a total gut, but you will take away some interesting knowledge from this and have a greater appreciation for the human body
Yes, but in a normal year!
Yes. Perfect science credit for non-science people. All memorization. Therefore, very accessible material.
Yes, especially if it is in person
Yes! I think it is great to know human osteology.
Yes!! It's really interesting
Yes, great course that allows you to use a different kind of thinking and learning.
Absolutely take this. Closest thing to a science gut, and actually interesting and useful material. GREAT COURSE
Yes! Just make sure to study well.
Heck yeah! If you like bones. If you don't like bones, don't take the class, because it's all memorizing bones.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student, if you're at all interested in anatomy! I learned so much, even more than I expected, and I really enjoyed this course as a whole.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual lecture.
N/A
A combination of live virtual lecture and virtual lab
